The reason you are having trouble testing the private method, is because 
you are using the reflection library to circumvent the access controls 
of the class - you are working against the very nature of the language.  
Yes its actually not that hard to do, but the point is, your tests are 
becoming more complicated and fragile as a result. 

Listen to your code.

With having such tests and their difficulties, its telling you that your 
design is 'questionable'.

If you have a private method, then it can only be accessed by another 
public interface on the class, therefore make life easier for yourself 
and everyone else on your team and test the private method VIA the 
public interface. 

If its difficult to test the private method via the public interface, 
then Listen To The Code..

1) .make the private method public...

or

2) Move the private method to its own class and make it public.


Can you post the Junit test and the class with the private and public 
methods here and we can work through it together?

Andrew
